ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Review of real analysis concepts through lens of topology, fundamental group, covering spaces, cell complexes.
Basic algebraic method to investigate topological problem.
Mostly an into to point set topology, with some discussion of fundamental groups in the second half of the semester.
I had not done any serious topology before this course, so this course gave me both a topology vocabulary and a solid understanding of some of the basics of algebraic topooogy.

Hatcher Point-Set Topology and Basic Results on First Fundamental Group: Functoriality, Van Kampen Theorem, etc. What is basically covered in Hatcher Algebraic Topology Chapter 1 but restricted to the study of loop homotopies.

General understanding of introductory topology (from connectedness through quotient spaces, homotopy equivalence, fundamental groups, and some of covering spaces). Roughly all of Hatcher's topology notes and through 1.3 in Hatcher topology.
Basic pointset topology, quotient spaces, Fundamental groups, van kampen theorem, covering spaces, etc.

Topology is mind-bending -- if you take this class you'll spend a lot of time thinking about gluing toruses together into a four dimensional sphere, and similar confounding but fascinating problems. This class equips you with some quite powerful tools to reason about these spaces, including the concepts of a quotient space, a covering space, and cell complexes.

In this class you learn the basic tools used in topology to categorize and understand spaces. You also develop skills in proof-based math because proofs are the main part of lecture, homework, and exams. The class also uses some algebra techniques during the second half, but these aren't as prevalent as other topological ideas.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Overall found the course to be on the lighter side in terms of work- although I wish that the office hour times were later on in the day/evening since I couldn't really ever go to them at noon.
The class is no well-structured.

Strengths:
- Understandable material
- Enjoyable lectures

Weaknesses:
- Some lectures were not well planned
I think the course has very interesting content and its strengths flow from that. It only becomes dry when we get bogged down in a highly technical proof for the day.

The class followed Hatchers book, which is quite advanced. Thus when we needed to diverge from Hatcher at some points, there was confusion and slowing down of the lectures. In terms of what was covered about the first fundamental group, very helpful!

Professor Kenyon cares a lot about math and his students--he was my only professor this semester to learn my name and use it in class. The topics of the course are generally interesting and it is pretty laid back. Grades were a little bit frustrating and I didn't really have any idea of what my final grade was going to be.

Professor Kenyon is a great strength of this class. His lectures feel more like conversations than the notes-based recitations that sound like you are being read to from the textbook. Professor Kenyon clearly thought carefully about what parts of the text merited highlighting, and took special care to find and spend time on intuition building examples. He invited students to help in fill in the logic in proofs, which made them much more engaging and understandable.

My only complaint about the course is that we spent quite a bit of time with basic concepts like open balls and compact sets, of the sort that those who have taken 230 or 305 are very familiar with. I wish we had moved through this material more quickly, to spend more time on the juicier topological ideas.

There are many difficult concepts in this course, and it can be very difficult to wrap your head around them. The homework gives you an opportunity to better understand them, but even that isn't quite enough. The textbook is also not very helpful. On the other hand, the material is very interesting, and the problem sets are not that intensive.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would certainly recommend this course. I learned a lot without the usual baggage that comes with upper level math courses with the insane workload. It seemed Kenyon was committed to interesting problem sets that did not take an absurd amount of time. Further, the lectures were engaging and interesting.
Probably only to math majors.
Its better to take with someone who work in algebraic topology specifically if you want to learn more. But if you just want to know a bit about the subject, it is good.
Yes, I recommend this course to any math major. Not overly challenging. Fun material to think about.
As long as they can handle it, they should definitely try it out!
Please take if you want to play around with some fun ideas! The workload in my year was relatively light, being 4-6 problems per week.
The subject is cool and Professor Kenyon is a cool guy. It's a relatively-low workload class and pretty easy to integrate into your schedule.
Absolutely! Great teaching and fascinating material. The smaller size of the class also makes it easier to ask questions.

This is a good math course because the material is very interesting. If you are taking this course, be sure to utilize office hours to ensure you fully understand the material. A slight lack of understanding can make it much harder to complete the homework or exams.
